texts.value: Catalyzes the formation of UDP-alpha-D-glucuronate, a constituent of complex glycosaminoglycans (PubMed:21961565, PubMed:21502315, PubMed:23106432, PubMed:22123821, PubMed:25478983, PubMed:27966912, PubMed:30420606, PubMed:30457329). Required for the biosynthesis of chondroitin sulfate and heparan sulfate. Required for embryonic development via its role in the biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycans (By similarity). Required for proper brain and neuronal development (PubMed:32001716)

reaction.name: H2O + 2 NAD(+) + UDP-alpha-D-glucose = 3 H(+) + 2 NADH + UDP-alpha-D-glucuronate

texts.value: UDP-alpha-D-xylose (UDX) acts as a feedback inhibitor. It binds at the same site as the substrate, but functions as allosteric inhibitor by triggering a conformation change that disrupts the active hexameric ring structure and gives rise to an inactive, horseshoe-shaped hexamer
kcat is 0.55 sec(-1) with UDP-glucose as substrate.
Nucleotide-sugar biosynthesis; UDP-alpha-D-glucuronate biosynthesis; UDP-alpha-D-glucuronate from UDP-alpha-D-glucose: step 1/1
Detected in heart, placenta, liver, pancreas, spleen, thymus, prostate, ovary, small intestine and colon (PubMed:9737970). Widely expressed (PubMed:9737970)

The protein goes through several conformation states during the reaction cycle, giving rise to hysteresis. In the initial state, the ligand-free protein is in an inactive conformation (E*). Substrate binding triggers a change to the active conformation (E). UDP-xylose binding triggers the transition to a distinct, inhibited conformation. The presence of an intrinsically disordered C-terminus promotes a more dynamic protein structure and favors a conformation with high affinity for UPD-xylose

The allosteric switch region moves by about 5 Angstroms when UDP-xylose is bound, and occupies part of the UDP-glucose binding site. At the same time it promotes domain movements that disrupt the active hexameric ring structure and lead to the formation of a horseshoe-shaped, inactive hexamer

disease.description: A form of epileptic encephalopathy, a heterogeneous group of severe early-onset epilepsies characterized by refractory seizures, neurodevelopmental impairment, and poor prognosis. Development is normal prior to seizure onset, after which cognitive and motor delays become apparent. DEE84 is an autosomal recessive form characterized by onset of refractory seizures in the first months of life.

texts.value: The disease is caused by variants affecting the gene represented in this entry
Belongs to the UDP-glucose/GDP-mannose dehydrogenase family

features.description: Important for formation of active hexamer structure
in DEE84; severely decreased protein stability; decreased hexamer formation; severe decrease of UDP-glucose 6-dehydrogenase activity; dbSNP:rs749975104

in DEE84; decreased function in glycosaminoglycan biosynthetic process in patient cells; severely decreased protein stability; decreased hexamer formation; severe decrease of UDP-glucose 6-dehydrogenase activity
in DEE84; unknown pathological significance; dbSNP:rs756467468
in DEE84; unknown pathological significance; dbSNP:rs1186496501
in DEE84; unknown pathological significance; may affect splicing

in DEE84; unknown pathological significance; dbSNP:rs770456604
in DEE84; unknown pathological significance; dbSNP:rs201894374
Loss of hexamer formation. Causes formation of stable dimers. Strongly reduced affinity for NAD and UDP-glucose, and strongly decreased catalytic efficiency at pH 8.6.
Impairs protein folding. Decreases affinity for UDP-glucose. No effect on inhibition by UDP-xylose. No effect on hysteresis and cooperativity.
No significant effect on catalytic activity and on affinity for NAD and UDP-glucose. Decreases affinity for the inhibitor UDP-xylose. Disrupts hysteresis and cooperativity.
Reduced affinity for UDP-glucose, and reduced catalytic efficiency.
Nearly abolishes enzyme activity. Stabilizes the enzyme in a low-activity hexameric conformation.
Stabilizes the active conformation of the hexamer. Decreases affinity for UDP-xylose, but not for UDP-glucose. Disrupts hysteresis and cooperativity.
Abolishes hydrolysis of the covalent intermediate between substrate and the catalytic cysteine residue.
Loss of hexamer formation. Causes formation of stable dimers. Strongly decreased specific activity at pH 8.4.
No effect on the intrinsically disordered nature of the C-terminus. No effect on affinity for the inhibitor UDP-xylose.
Strongly decreases affinity for the inhibitor UDP-xylose.
